OK, welcome everyone.
My name is Peter Mika and I've been coaching the semantic web change this year together with Jim Hendler who unfortunately couldn't be here for the closing ceremony.
So I have a couple of slides about the challenge.

For those of you who haven't been to any of the events, the challenge is a competition where we'd like the participants to showcase semantic web technology by using it in applications, and the idea is to stimulate research and applications by showing what is visible using semantic technologies.
It serves an informal benchmark for this community to compare results and to measure progress in this field.
This is the sixth challenge this year.
We've been organizing it every year, and as you see this year, what is new in the format is that we have two tracks and open track and a billion triples track.
They differ in their in their intent.
The open track is what we used to have before as the Semantic Web challenge, and it's focused on end user applications of semantic technologies.
While the billion triples track is focused on dealing with the scalability and heterogeneity problems that we see.
In dealing with large scale web data.
The difference there is that we have a data set that's provided to the to the participant.
And the submission is not required to be an end user application, although most of the submissions that we have received had some kind of end user interface.

Because of this, because of this, billion triples track and the commitments related to that, we had a late submission deadline to leave the participants enough time to work, and many of them made very good use of that and worked until the very last minute.
So that's why this year we don't have the papers online, but I encourage you to go to the website challenge.semanticweb.org to see the papers and see the systems as well.
In summary, I can say about this challenge that we've seen some truly inspiring applications in the open track.
Really, applications that we can proudly show off to anyone who is not even expert in semantic technologies to see what is possible in this domain.
And a billion triples track is really the place where some of the innovations are happening in terms of dealing with the kind of data that we're starting to get.
Now that semantic technologies are widely in use on the web.
Altogether, we had 24 submissions from which we accepted 2213 of these submissions for the open track and nine for the billion triples track.
And as you can see, this is an increase in the number of submissions compared to previous years.

There was less diversity in terms of geography, which probably has to do with the place of the conference being in being in Europe, we had 18 submissions from the U2 from China, one from Canada and one from the US.
Largely from academic institutions, but also from private organizations.
Ranging from individual contributions to two large national projects altogether in the past six years, we have seen already more than hundreds submit.
So what was the process that we followed much like in previous years?
The systems were judged by an expert panel.
Who I would like to thank for their for their work on this and they truly deserve a round of applause.
In particular because they had a much more difficult task than in previous years, namely part of the evaluation took place at the conference.
It took place in two rounds in the first round, based on the submitted descriptions.
The online demos and demos presented in the poster session post random session.
We selected the top five systems in each category and then our judges had a second round of evaluation during the presentation session.
There they judged each application based on detailed criteria.
The criteria are not mystery.

They're actually in the in the call for call for papers for the open track, the emphasis is on as I already mentioned, after genius distributed systems that deal with the open world setting on the web.
There's an emphasis on formal descriptions using using ontologies and and reusing ontologies and data where possible.
Big criteria is obviously, and it's not there because it's an entry criteria is to have an end user application that is designed for a casual user.
On the billion triple stack in the other hand, the focus is on the data set on using our data set and adding value to it in some sense.
Obviously scalability is important, so we looked at whether the system could potentially scale even beyond one billion triples.
And again, since the data comes from the web, there are issues related to heterogeneity and the notion of an open world.
There additional desirables for which the systems got extra extra credits ranging from whether there have been formally vacations.
Weather data have been demonstrated.
Usage of the system already, and so on and so on.
Right?
So as I already mentioned, this was the process and in the end from those five finalists we have selected the three prize winners in each category.
Again, I encourage you to visit the website for more details.
As in previous years we are also planning to submit the best systems and create special issue in one of the journals.
Most likely the general web semantics which has carried the best paper best papers from this event in previous years.
So I would like to thank all the participants and the judges.

For those of you who haven't been to any of the events, the challenge is a competition where we'd like the participants to showcase semantic web technology by using it in applications, and the idea is to stimulate research and applications by showing what is visible using semantic technologies.
It serves an informal benchmark for this community to compare results and to measure progress in this field.
This is the sixth challenge this year.
We've been organizing it every year, and as you see this year, what is new in the format is that we have two tracks and open track and a billion triples track.
They differ in their in their intent.
The open track is what we used to have before as the Semantic Web challenge, and it's focused on end user applications of semantic technologies.
While the billion triples track is focused on dealing with the scalability and heterogeneity problems that we see.
In dealing with large scale web data.
The difference there is that we have a data set that's provided to the to the participant.
And the submission is not required to be an end user application, although most of the submissions that we have received had some kind of end user interface.

Because of this, because of this, billion triples track and the commitments related to that, we had a late submission deadline to leave the participants enough time to work, and many of them made very good use of that and worked until the very last minute.
So that's why this year we don't have the papers online, but I encourage you to go to the website challenge.semanticweb.org to see the papers and see the systems as well.
In summary, I can say about this challenge that we've seen some truly inspiring applications in the open track.
Really, applications that we can proudly show off to anyone who is not even expert in semantic technologies to see what is possible in this domain.
And a billion triples track is really the place where some of the innovations are happening in terms of dealing with the kind of data that we're starting to get.
Now that semantic technologies are widely in use on the web.
Altogether, we had 24 submissions from which we accepted 2213 of these submissions for the open track and nine for the billion triples track.
And as you can see, this is an increase in the number of submissions compared to previous years.

There was less diversity in terms of geography, which probably has to do with the place of the conference being in being in Europe, we had 18 submissions from the U2 from China, one from Canada and one from the US.
Largely from academic institutions, but also from private organizations.
Ranging from individual contributions to two large national projects altogether in the past six years, we have seen already more than hundreds submit.

The systems were judged by an expert panel.
Who I would like to thank for their for their work on this and they truly deserve a round of applause.

The online demos and demos presented in the poster session post random session.
We selected the top five systems in each category and then our judges had a second round of evaluation during the presentation session.
There they judged each application based on detailed criteria.
